instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2530: What is 820-2530? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.D6905: What is D6905? Diode sitting between PPBUS_G3H/PP18V5 charger voltage and PP3V42_G3H power supply input on very old Macbooks(before 2011), can die and cause PP3V42_G3H to be missing and have no input voltage. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.ADAPTER_SENSE: What is ADAPTER_SENSE? This is a line between the onewire circuit and the magsafe charger where the magsafe charger can talk to the SMC(system management controller) on the SYS_ONEWIRE line..
definitions.R6905: What is R6905? Resistor between charger voltage and input to PP3V42_G3H power supply on older Macbooks, pre-2011 models. This resistor blows when C6990 has shorted to ground or U6990 has shorted to ground, and will result in PP3V42_G3H missing and the magsafe charger not having a light since PP3V42_G3H is necessary for the SMC to turn on and the onewire circuit to turn on..
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.C6990: What is C6990? Capacitor to ground on input to PP3V42_G3H power supply. PP3V42_G3H power supply turns 18.5v from charger or 8.5v-12.5v PPBUS_G3H from the battery into PP3V42_G3H. This capacitor can short to ground and keep PP3V42_G3H from turning on which would keep the machine from having a light on the magsafe charger.
definitions.C7771: What is C7771? Tantalum capacitor on 820-2330 and 820-2532 logic boards that often dies and causes PP1V05_S5_MCP or PP1V05_S5 to be 0.331v instead of 1.05v. If heating this cap restores voltage to this rail, replace.
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H? PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H is the input voltage to the PP3V42_G3H buck converter circuit, it can be either charger voltage or battery voltage depending on what the system power source is. This often shorts to ground when one of the input capacitors dies. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or s3/s0 rails
threads.message:
This board was liquid damaged on the top side of the board. I have cleaned and replaced all of the damaged components in that area such as <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>, <RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR>, <DIODE>D6905</DIODE>, <CHIP>U6901</CHIP> plus other caps&resistors.

The magsafe connector on the logic board had some corrosion on the <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> pin which I assume is the reason why I'm not getting any voltage on adapter sense but even when I inject 3.3v on the <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> pin of the magsafe and plug the charger in I still get no green light except for a very dim one. I get 3.4v on pins 1/4&5 of <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> but still no green light and <RESISTOR>R6929</RESISTOR> measures good.

I have used 2 different known working magsafe boards.

I have 12.6v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and 3.3v on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> but when I jump the power pads to turn this on nothing turns on.

Resistance to ground on Pins 1/4 of Y2810 is around 11.5Megaohms.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or s3/s0 rails
threads.message:
Update: I ultrasonic'd the board and plugged in the charger afterwards and I got a green light. I jumped the on off pads and the fan spun so I assumed this was working so I put it in the assembly, plugged the cables in then the battery. When I plugged the charger in the light was dim and after a little while I noticed <RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR> was sizzling. Under the microscope when I plug the charger in <RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR> gets so hot to the point where the solder on the pads melt and if I touch it it will move.

I put another <RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR> on the board and again it did the same thing.
In diode mode Pins 6&8 of <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> are 0.004v to ground. <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is around 0.30v to ground and <RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR> is 0.66v to ground.

The pads on Pins 6/8 of <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> were gone and I had to run wires under the chip so I'm not sure if that is causing this short and previously Pins 6/8 of <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> would start smoking a little but for some reason the short went away.
I replaced <CAPACITOR>C6990</CAPACITOR> before so I don't think that could be causing the short.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or s3/s0 rails
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or s3/s0 rails
threads.message:
As soon as a I plug the charger in <RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR> starts smoking up and I didn't want to let it cause further damage but for that quick second I tried to measure and I didn't get any voltage on <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR>.
I think my issue right now is that Pins 6/8 of <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> are shorted to ground and I'm not sure why. I am no longer getting a green light. Once I get a green light this should start working again.

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is 0.32v in diode mode.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or s3/s0 rails
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or s3/s0 rails
threads.message:
I removed <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> and <CAPACITOR>C6990</CAPACITOR> but the short on <SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H</SIGNAL> is still there. The only difference is that now in diode mode it went up to 0.014v.
The pads for Pins 6/8 of <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> were gone so could the short be inside the board and if so is there anything I could do to get around it?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or s3/s0 rails
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or s3/s0 rails
threads.message: Short in the board. Lift all connections and make your own rail. Or just trash this antique.....

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or s3/s0 rails
threads.message:
I attached an image of the area.
[USER="2"]dukefawks[/USER]
When you say "lift all connections" what would be the best way to go about doing that?
I would just give this back to the customer but I know it works because I was able to get it turning on right after ultrasonic cleaning the board. It was once I put it in the housing and plugged everything in that it did this again.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or s3/s0 rails
threads.message: Use you imagination to isolate all pins from the board and run some wires between them

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or s3/s0 rails
threads.message:
Okay I ran a bunch of wires to get around the short and now I get a green light and the fan spins when I short the pads.

I get 1.06v on <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> and L7770 but should I replace <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> because I believe they cause issues and if so what do I replace it with?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or s3/s0 rails
threads.message: Does the board boot at least?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or s3/s0 rails
threads.message: Yes it booted and works fine.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or s3/s0 rails
threads.message:
Replace <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> as a precaution.

Scrap that, this is not the infamous 330uF. Board is fixed and done.
